metadata.titleEn: Southeast Tibet station of Chinese Academy of Sciences: basic meteorological data of forest line on the east slope of Sejila Mountain (2021)
metadata.description:
1) Data content (including elements and significance): the data includes the daily values of air temperature (℃), precipitation (mm), relative humidity (%), wind speed (M / s) and radiation (w / m2)
2) Data source and processing method; Air temperature, relative humidity, radiation and wind speed are daily mean values, and precipitation is daily cumulative value; Data collection location: 29 ° 39 ′ 25.2 ″ n near the forest line on the east slope of Sejila Mountain; 94°42′25.62″E;  4390m； The underlying surface is natural grassland; Collector model Campbell Co CR1000, acquisition time: 10 minutes. Digital automatic data acquisition. The temperature and relative humidity instrument probe is hmp155a; The wind speed sensor is 05103; The precipitation is te525mm; The radiation is li200x;
3) Data quality description; The original data of air temperature, relative humidity and wind speed are the average value of 10 minutes, and the precipitation is the cumulative value of 10 minutes; The daily average temperature, relative humidity, precipitation and wind speed are obtained by arithmetic average or summation. Due to the limitation of the sensor, the precipitation in winter may have a certain error.
4) Data application achievements and prospects: this data is the update of the existing data "Sejila Mountain meteorological data (2007-2017)" and "basic meteorological data of Sejila east slope forest line of South Tibet station of Chinese Academy of Sciences (2018)". The data time scale span is large, which is convenient for scientists or graduate students in Atmospheric Physics, ecology and atmospheric environment. This data will be updated from time to time every year.
metadata.instructions: The file is named as the basic meteorological data (2021) of the forest line on the east slope of Sejila Mountain at the Southeast Tibet station of Chinese Academy of Sciences, which can be opened by Excel or WPS

background: In mountainous areas, different altitudes exhibit distinct vertical zonation due to variations in water (precipitation) and heat (temperature) components. The Sejila Mountain in southeastern Tibet has a pronounced mountain vertical zonation feature: from the foot of the mountain to the summit, the vegetation types include broadleaf forest, mixed coniferous and broadleaf forest, coniferous forest, shrubs, and moss. The vegetation types in Sejila Mountain are rich, and the longevity of trees is notable (Lu et al., 2015). The tree line at 4390 m is one of the highest forest tree lines in the world, making it a hotspot for tree-ring and forest ecology research (Wang et al., 2014; Liang et al., 2016; Shen et al., 2018). Currently, there is limited research on the vertical gradients of temperature and precipitation in Sejila Mountain (Liang et al., 2011). Most studies by some scholars on the changes in temperature and precipitation vertical gradients in this region and its vicinity are based on the Baji Station (formerly Linzhi Station) and the nearby Bomi Station, focusing on the vertical temperature lapse rate across the entire Tibetan Plateau (Jiang Jingchao et al., 2016; Guo et al., 2016; Li et al., 2013; Wang et al., 2001, 2018; Zhang et al., 2018) and precipitation gradients (Guo et al., 2016).
research objective: Therefore, this article explores the vertical variation patterns of temperature and precipitation on the eastern and western slopes of the Sejila Mountain based on temperature and precipitation data from 11 meteorological stations. This not only deepens the understanding of the influence of slope orientation on the vertical gradient changes of temperature and precipitation in Sejila Mountain but also helps to better understand the physiological and ecological characteristics of plant and animal distribution with altitude changes. Additionally, it provides reliable data support for future hydrological simulations in this region.
challenges: Due to the many factors affecting the vertical temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient, among the meteorological stations in the Sejila Mountains, except for the mountain pass station, tree line station, and ecological station located on the ridge, all other stations are situated in valley areas. Additionally, the western slope and high-altitude stations are relatively few, which may affect the accuracy of the temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient obtained in this study.
methods: The data for this study includes daily temperature and precipitation records (from April to October) from 2013 to 2018 provided by the Linzhi Meteorological Bureau of the Tibet Autonomous Region, covering nine stations: Bayi, Niche, Station 114, Station 113, Shankou, Ecological Station, Rulang, Bing Station, and Layue, as well as the main station of Southeast Tibet (shown in Figure 1 and Table 1) and two stations at the tree line. Based on the geographical locations of these stations, the stations in the Sejila Mountain area are divided into two natural geographical units according to their slope orientation: the western slope (south slope) and the eastern slope (north slope), with the Sejila Mountain Pass station belonging to both the western and eastern slopes. The vertical temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient are estimated through regression analysis based on the elevation of the stations and the temperature or precipitation amounts.
dataset: The data for this study includes daily temperature and precipitation values (from April to October) from 2013 to 2018 provided by the Linzhi Meteorological Bureau of the Tibet Autonomous Region for nine stations: Bayi, Niche, Station 114, Station 113, Shankou, Ecological Station, Rulang, Bing Station, and Layu Station, as well as the main station of Southeast Tibet Station (shown in Figure 1 and Table 1) and two stations at the tree line.
findings: From 2013 to 2018, the average temperature lapse rate (λ) at 11 stations on the Selila Mountain ranged from 0.59 to 0.63 °C·(100 m)^-1, with the lowest λ value in 2016 and the highest in 2014. The average λ from 2013 to 2018 was 0.60 °C·(100 m)^-1. The western slope had λ values ranging from 0.69 to 0.72 °C·(100 m)^-1, with the lowest λ in 2016 and the highest in 2014, and an average λ of 0.71 °C·(100 m)^-1 from 2013 to 2018. The eastern slope had λ values between 0.53 and 0.55 °C·(100 m)^-1; unlike the Selila Mountain and western slope, the lowest λ was in 2015 and the highest in 2017, with an average λ of 0.55 °C·(100 m)^-1 from 2013 to 2018. From 2013 to 2018, the average precipitation gradient on the eastern slope was 10.5 mm·(100 m)^-1, with the monsoon period showing a trend of first increasing, then decreasing, and then increasing again with elevation; during the non-monsoon period, the trend was first decreasing, then increasing. The precipitation gradient above the southeastern Tibet station was notably significant.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to gather meteorological data in mountainous regions?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used in mountainous regions involves using automated digital sensors such as Campbell Co CR1000 with a 10-minute interval. This setup includes instruments like HMP155A for temperature and relative humidity, 05103 for wind speed, TE525MM for precipitation, and Li200X for radiation, as applied near the treeline on the southeast slope of Sejila Mountain.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when estimating temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountainous areas?
Example.Answer: A challenge in estimating temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients is the limited number of high-altitude stations and the fact that most stations are located in valleys, which can lead to less accurate estimates of lapse rates and gradients, as experienced in the Sejila Mountain region.

Definition.Question: What is meant by '日值数据' in the context of meteorological data collection?
Definition.Answer: '日值数据' refers to daily value data that is collected and recorded for various meteorological parameters such as temperature, precipitation, relative humidity, wind speed, and radiation. These daily values are derived from measurements taken at regular intervals, such as every 10 minutes, and provide an average or cumulative figure for each day.

Definition.Question: How is '数据质量描述' significant in the context of data collection for meteorological studies?
Definition.Answer: '数据质量描述' is significant as it provides an assessment of the accuracy and reliability of the data collected in meteorological studies. It describes how original measurements, such as temperature, relative humidity, and wind speed, are averaged over specific intervals (e.g., 10 minutes) and accumulated (e.g., precipitation) to obtain daily values. It also highlights potential errors, such as those in winter precipitation measurements due to sensor limitations.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods for basic meteorological data using automatic digital collection compare between the 林线站 and other meteorological stations in the 色季拉山 region in terms of frequency and accuracy?
Comparison.Answer: The data collection method using automatic digital collection at the 林线站 involves a 10-minute interval, and the data are averaged or summed for daily values. Other stations, like 巴宜 and others in the 色季拉山 region, provide daily values for specific months, focusing more on seasonal patterns. The automatic collection at 林线站 might offer more frequent data but could face accuracy issues in winter due to sensor limitations.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences and similarities in data quality challenges faced by meteorological data collection at 林线站 compared to other meteorological stations in the 色季拉山 region?
Comparison.Answer: Both the 林线站 and other meteorological stations in the 色季拉山 region face challenges in data quality due to geographical and sensor limitations. At 林线站, there is a noted potential error in winter precipitation measurements due to sensor limitations. Other stations might also face challenges due to their location, such as being in valleys or having fewer high-altitude stations, which could impact the accuracy of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges could arise from using automatic digital data collection systems in areas with extreme weather conditions, such as high altitudes or cold temperatures?
Interpretation.Answer: In high-altitude or cold regions, challenges such as sensor limitations can affect data accuracy, especially in winter when precipitation measurements may be prone to errors. The durability and calibration of sensors like those measuring temperature, humidity, and wind speed must be carefully managed to ensure reliable data collection.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways can datasets from different meteorological stations be integrated to enhance the understanding of climatic variations across a region like Sejila Mountain?
Interpretation.Answer: Datasets from various meteorological stations can be integrated by analyzing their geographical locations and categorizing them into natural geographic units, such as eastern and western slopes. This allows for a comprehensive understanding of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients across these units, potentially providing insights into the physiological ecology of flora and fauna and supporting hydrological modeling in the region.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the potential errors in precipitation data collection during the winter season?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Due to sensor limitations, there might be certain inaccuracies in measuring winter precipitation, as highlighted in the data quality description.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the variation in temperature lapse rates on the eastern and western slopes of mountain regions like Sejila Mountain?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variation in temperature lapse rates is influenced by factors such as the geographical positioning of meteorological stations on either the western or eastern slopes, affecting the vertical temperature gradient and precipitation distribution.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to obtain accurate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountain regions with few high-altitude stations?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges arise from the limited number of high-altitude stations, especially on the western slopes, and most stations being located in valley areas, which can impact the accuracy of temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient estimations.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using a 10-minute interval data collection method for meteorological variables on the accuracy of daily average calculations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a 10-minute interval data collection method allows for detailed temporal resolution, which improves the accuracy of daily average calculations for variables like temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, and radiation. However, for precipitation, there might be certain inaccuracies during winter due to sensor limitations, potentially affecting the cumulative daily values.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of using geographically diverse meteorological stations on the estimation of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using geographically diverse meteorological stations allows for more comprehensive estimation of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients by providing a wider range of data across different altitudes and slopes. However, factors such as station location in valleys versus ridges and limited high-altitude stations may impact the accuracy and representativeness of these estimates.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of collecting meteorological data from multiple stations across different elevations in mountainous regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to explore the vertical changes in temperature and precipitation on both the eastern and western slopes of the mountain, enhancing the understanding of how slope orientation affects these gradients. This data is crucial for understanding the physiological and ecological characteristics of flora and fauna distribution across different altitudes and provides reliable data to support future hydrological simulations in the region.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intended benefits of using automated digital data collection methods in remote, high-altitude meteorological stations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended benefits include ensuring consistent and accurate collection of meteorological data such as temperature, humidity, wind speed, precipitation, and radiation, despite harsh environmental conditions. Automated methods reduce human error, enable continuous monitoring, and allow for real-time data analysis, which is essential for understanding complex ecological and climatic processes in remote areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instruments and procedural steps are involved in collecting and processing meteorological data in high-altitude forest lines?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The data collection involves using instruments such as a Campbell Co CR1000 data logger with a 10-minute collection interval. Temperature and relative humidity are measured using an HMP155A probe, wind speed with a 05103 sensor, precipitation with a TE525MM, and radiation with a Li200X. The data processing includes calculating daily averages for temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, and radiation, while precipitation is accumulated daily.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can meteorological data from diverse altitudes and topographies be systematically collected and analyzed to understand temperature and precipitation gradients?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Meteorological data is collected from multiple stations positioned at different altitudes and topographies, such as ridges and valleys, to capture the vertical variation in temperature and precipitation. The data are then subjected to regression analysis based on station elevation to estimate the temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient, aiding in the understanding of their vertical changes.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the collection of meteorological data in high-altitude forest lines?
Enablement.Answer: The use of digital automatic data collection systems, such as the Campbell Co CR1000 with a 10-minute data collection interval, has enabled the collection of precise meteorological data like temperature, humidity, wind speed, and radiation at high-altitude forest lines.

Enablement.Question: How do data collection methods address the challenge of accurately measuring winter precipitation in high-altitude regions?
Enablement.Answer: Winter precipitation measurements may have certain errors due to sensor limitations, indicating a need for improved data collection methods or sensor technologies that can better handle extreme weather conditions in high-altitude regions.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do geographic variations impact the estimation of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients in mountainous regions?
Enablement.Answer: Geographic variations, such as the location of meteorological stations in valleys versus ridges, and the limited number of high-altitude stations, can impact the accuracy of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradient estimations in mountainous regions like the southeast Tibet Sejila Mountain area.

Expectation.Question: Why might the data collection methods used for capturing meteorological data at high altitudes like the treeline on Sejila Mountain face challenges in ensuring accuracy during winter months?
Expectation.Answer: The data quality description indicates that due to sensor limitations, winter precipitation measurements may have certain errors. This suggests that extreme weather conditions or sensor malfunctions could be challenges that affect data accuracy.

Expectation.Question: Why might the anticipated temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient studies be affected by the distribution of meteorological stations in mountain valley areas rather than ridge locations?
Expectation.Answer: The challenges section notes that many meteorological stations are situated in valley areas, and fewer are at high-altitude sites, which could impact the ability to obtain accurate temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients, particularly affecting the representativeness of the data for ridge conditions.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the challenges faced in accurately collecting meteorological data in high-altitude regions like the forest line at 4390m, and how can these challenges be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: One of the challenges is the potential error in winter precipitation measurements due to sensor limitations. Addressing this may involve using more advanced or specialized sensors that are better suited for cold environments. Additionally, the geographical placement of stations, with more in valley areas and fewer on higher altitudes, might affect data accuracy. Expanding the network to include more high-altitude stations could improve data reliability.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential methodological improvements that could enhance the accuracy of temperature and precipitation gradient estimations in mountainous regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Improving accuracy could involve refining regression analysis methods used to estimate temperature and precipitation gradients, considering more diverse factors influencing these gradients. Additionally, increasing the spatial coverage of meteorological stations, especially in underrepresented areas like the west slope or higher altitudes, could provide more comprehensive data for analysis.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the potential for using historical datasets in combination with recent data to advance understanding of temperature and precipitation changes in regions like the southeastern Tibetan Plateau?
Judgmental.Answer: Combining historical datasets with recent data provides a broader temporal analysis, allowing for the study of long-term trends and changes. This approach can yield insights into the effects of climate change over time and improve the accuracy of predictive models for future conditions. However, ensuring data consistency and addressing any discrepancies in data collection methods over time would be crucial.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the daily values of temperature, precipitation, relative humidity, and wind speed are computed from data collected every 10 minutes.
Assertion.Answer: The daily values are computed by averaging or summing the 10-minute interval data. Temperature, relative humidity, and wind speed are averaged, while precipitation is summed to get the daily values.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how the geographical positioning of meteorological stations affects the accuracy of vertical temperature and precipitation gradients.
Assertion.Answer: The location of meteorological stations, whether on ridges or in valleys, can influence the accuracy of vertical gradients due to varying environmental factors, such as wind patterns or local climate conditions. For instance, most stations are in valleys, which may affect the accuracy of the temperature lapse rate and precipitation gradient calculations.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about how the limitations of sensors could impact the accuracy of winter precipitation data.
Assertion.Answer: Due to sensor limitations, there might be inaccuracies in measuring winter precipitation. This could be because of factors like the type of precipitation (e.g., snow vs. rain) or sensor sensitivity at low temperatures, which can lead to errors in the recorded data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe data collection methods that can effectively capture daily variations in temperature, precipitation, humidity, wind speed, and radiation in mountainous regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: A data collection method that can effectively capture daily variations in these parameters involves using automated data loggers like the Campbell Co CR1000 with specific sensors for each parameter. The temperature and humidity can be measured using the HMP155A probe, wind speed with the 05103 sensor, precipitation with the TE525MM gauge, and radiation with the Li200X sensor. Data should be collected at regular intervals, such as every 10 minutes, and processed to obtain daily averages or accumulations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential challenges in collecting accurate meteorological data in high-altitude forest line areas and suggest approaches to overcome them.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential challenges include sensor limitations leading to errors, especially in winter precipitation measurements, and the sparse distribution of high-altitude stations which may affect the accuracy of temperature lapse rates and precipitation gradients. To overcome these, ensure regular maintenance and calibration of sensors, employ redundant or diverse sensor types to cross-validate data, and expand the network of monitoring stations to include more high-altitude and varied slope locations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose a research approach to enhance the understanding of temperature and precipitation vertical gradients in mountainous areas using multiple meteorological datasets.
Request/Directive.Answer: A research approach could involve using regression analysis to correlate temperature and precipitation data from multiple meteorological stations at different altitudes and orientations (e.g., east and west slopes). Obtain data from local meteorological bureaus and integrate it with data from other regional stations to estimate vertical gradients. This approach can deepen the understanding of slope effects on climatic conditions and support ecological and hydrological modeling efforts in mountainous regions.
